text: The night hangs low, the snow outside whispering like fine sand against the windows. Only one lamp remains lit; the hearth casts a warm ring along the edge of the table.
The last guest leaves. I slide the bolt into place. A final pot of soup still simmers, but its scent feels half-swallowed by the dark.
Alicia stands beside the counter, already back in her familiar cloak. She doesn’t rush to leave—like she’s waiting for me to finish the last small task.
Her movements are steady. Too steady for someone who was just playing innkeeper. That brief warmth—the “landlady” version of her—folds away like thin paper tucked back into a pocket.
“You’re going out?”
“Mm.”
She tightens her gloves. Her knuckles pale slightly.
“I have to visit the Echo Circle.”
“Now? This late?”
“Later is better.”
She says it simply, like naming a required stop along a route.
“What are you going to do?”
“Take something.”
She pauses, as if dragging the key word up from somewhere deep.
“Their leader’s token. A necklace.”
“You’re getting it tonight?”
“Yes.”
“If I don’t, everything’s wasted.”
She fastens her cloak. When she looks at me, there’s no hesitation—only the clarity of someone pushed to the edge.
“I don’t want to drag this out anymore.”
“That’s dangerous.”
“I know.”
She steps closer, closing the space between us—not threatening, just urgent. She needs me to understand.
“I don’t need you to prove you’re brave.”
“I need you alive.”
“You say that every time.”
The words leave my mouth before I can stop them. I shouldn’t have said “every time.”
Her pupils tighten slightly—then ease, like she’s accepted that I’m already being drawn into this.
“…Yes.”
“Because I don’t have much left I can afford to lose.”
She presses a cold metal clasp into my palm. Not a gift—more like a seal. If I don’t come back, don’t follow.
“Bolt the door.”
“Don’t be reckless.”
She turns to leave. Her steps are light—but it feels like she takes half the air in the room with her.

options.text: Option B: Stay at the inn  【DC 0】
